GlossaryCacheEntry.Definition: A fundamental ingredient in Korean cooking, gochujang is a thick, spicy paste made from red chilli flakes, sticky rice, fermented soybeans and salt.
Also known as aka (the Japanese word for red) miso, red miso is saltier with a stronger flavor than other varieties. It can easily overwhelm milder ingredients, so use sparingly.
A clay pot for use over an open flame. Often, food is cooked at the table on a gas burner. The clay retains its heat for a long time, ideal for keeping food warm during a lengthy meal.
Also known as shiro (the Japanese word for white) miso, white miso is fermented for a shorter time and lower in salt than red and brown miso. It has a mild, sweet flavor.
A cooked mix of flour and water, used to soften bread and increase shelf life.
A member of the kelp family, kombu is a source of glutamic acid, responsible for umami. Kombu is used to make dashi.
Crumbs made from tempura batter. It is commonly used as a batter filling or topping for texture.
A dried and powdered green seaweed. Most commonly used as a topping for okonomiyaki and takoyaki
Mayonnaise made from egg yolks only. Essential for topping okonomiyaki and takoyaki.
Smoked and fermented skipjack tuna that forms the base of dashi stock.
A stock that is the backbone of Japanese food. Dashi forms the base for miso soup, broths, and ramen to accentuate umami
Originating in China, tofu is formed from coagulated soy curds that are pressed into blocks of varying softness. Low in calories and high in protein, it is often used as a meat substitute.
A dried, edible seaweed frequently used in Japanese cuisine. Due to its strong flavour it is often used to wrap sushi or onigiri, or as a ramen topping.
An additive that is commonly added to foods as a thickener or stabiliser, and is frequently used to help bind gluten free baked goods.
A type of rice wine commonly found in Japanese cuisine. It is similar to sake, but with a lower sugar and alcohol content.
